column4: A pity games don't work better on Linux.  It's really the only thing tying me to windows.  It'd be nice if they worked on macs too.
- You'll be happy to know that I've been able to run any of my Windows games (including intense 3d) without a problem in Linux ;)
Some games have native ports, but believe me, I've had nothing but misery trying to run stuff in wine and cedega
- ahh, I use Wine right now... haven't had a problem.  Been using Linux for over a week now and see no reason whatsoever to go back to Windows...
- even my computer illiterate family has migrated to Linux with absolute ease (of course, I sweat and toiled to get it working right for them)
No doubt.  It depends on what you want to run, I think.

I did migrate my mother to Linux.  Linux is easy to use, it's just much harder for people at the 'just enough knowledge to be dangerous' stage; it's harder to install third-party programs, hardware, etc.

I wish they'd make a synaptic-like program for third-party software, so it'd be easy for companies to sell commercial software for linux; a lot of stuff will probably never have good OSS equivilents, like greeting card software, etc. that no one wants to code.
- they don't need greeting card software.  use Scribus ;)
Well, that was just an example
- aside from games, I've been able to find a native linux app for everything I used in Windows... EVERYTHING.

Yeah, but there's some things that don't have equivilent programs.  Photoshop, and desktop publishing software, is the best example; GIMP is nowhere near that level, and I don't know of any wysiwyg desktop publishing software that is remotely competitive.
- what DTP do you use in Windows?
I don't use anything anymore, but when I did, it was Quark.
- hmm... the only thing I ever used in Windows was MS Pub...
MS Pub was not considered even up to the level of other commercial windows DTPs when I worked in that field, and I don't know of any OSS equivilent to that, even.
yeah, I wasn't exactly using it for professional reasons.  But I've heard Scribus is quite good.

as far as Photoshop goes, apparently Gimp is getting closer to that level all the time.  And with GimpShop (something I'm struggling to install) it supposedly mimicks the PhotoShop environment pretty well.
I'll check it out.  I would LIKE to discover an OSS DTP that was worthwhile, I just haven't.
No, it doesn't.  The interface, even with gimpshop, makes me want to drive an icepick into my temple.
well, that would be unfortunate ;)
the GIMP interface is utterly humiliated even by something like Paint Shop Pro.  It's just terrible.
I'll be honest, though.  Using The Gimp drives me nuts too because that whole multiple window interface is the stupid fricken thing I've ever heard of.
That's the most obvious and egregious problem, but there's a lot else wrong with it too.
